courseDescription: An introductory course designed to acquaint the student with the basic principles of chemistry.
Technical and Digital Skills: Safety protocols in a lab setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying mathematical concepts to chemical problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on course topics

courseDescription: This course is the first part of a two-semester sequence of chemistry covering topics in general, organic, and biological chemistry.  In this part, an introduction to the principles of inorganic (general) chemistry is provided.  The topics to be covered include measurements, atoms and elements, compounds and their bonds, energy and matter, gases, solutions, acids and bases, chemical reactions and quantities, chemical equilibrium, and nuclear chemistry.  This course does not meet the prerequisite for CHEM 123N, and cannot be used toward the CHEM major or minor.  Students wishing to pursue advanced study in chemistry should take CHEM 121N, CHEM 122N, CHEM 123N, and CHEM 124N.  Credit for CHEM 105N is not allowed if a student has prior credit for CHEM 121N.  CHEM 105N + CHEM 106N satisfy four credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of energy and matter in chemical reactions
Understanding gases and solutions in chemistry
Knowledge of acids, bases, and chemical equilibrium
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in solving chemistry problems
Applying principles of chemistry to real-world scenarios

courseDescription: An introduction to common laboratory techniques and the process of science is provided.  CHEM 105N + CHEM 106N satisfy four credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying sources of error in experiments

courseDescription: This course is the second part of a two-semester sequence of chemistry covering topics in general, organic, and biological chemistry.  In this part, an introduction to organic compounds and their role in biological systems is provided.  The topics to be covered include the structure, nomenclature, and reactivity of organic compounds, the structure and function of important biomolecules, and the chemistry of metabolic pathways.  This course does not meet the prerequisite for CHEM 211, and cannot be used toward the CHEM major or minor.  Students wishing to pursue advanced study in chemistry should take CHEM 121N, CHEM 122N, CHEM 123N, and CHEM 124N.  CHEM 107N + CHEM 108N satisfy four credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key components of metabolic pathways

courseDescription: Laboratory experiments involving organic compounds and biomolecules are performed.  CHEM 107N + CHEM 108N satisfy four credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying sources of error in experiments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively in laboratory experiments

courseTitle: Foundations of Chemistry I Laboratory for Online Degree Programs
courseDescription: In this course, students perform laboratory experiments to complement the topics presented in the companion lecture course, CHEM 121N.  CHEM 121N + CHEM 120 does not satisfy the university's Nature of Science requirement. This is a distance learning course restricted to students in an online degree program.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying sources of error in experiments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively for lab assignments
Taking initiative in coordinating with lab partners

courseDescription: This is the first of a two-course series, designed for science and engineering majors, that prepares the student for subsequent studies in molecular science and constitutes the foundation for all upper-level chemistry courses. Topics include the descriptive chemistry of selected elements, modern atomic and molecular structure, stoichiometry, thermochemistry, and gas laws. A student receiving credit for CHEM 121N cannot receive additional credit for CHEM 103 or CHEM 105N. CHEM 121N + CHEM 122N satisfy 4 credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement. Pre- or
Technical and Digital Skills: Modern atomic and molecular structure analysis

courseDescription: Laboratory experiments are designed to complement the topics presented in the companion lecture course, CHEM 121N.  A student receiving credit for CHEM 122N cannot receive additional credit for CHEM 106N.  CHEM 121N + CHEM 122N satisfy 4 credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Recording and analyzing experimental data using software
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating experimental procedures and results clearly
Seeking help or clarification when needed
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data to draw conclusions about chemical reactions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time efficiently during lab sessions
Taking initiative in setting up experiments
Assuming leadership roles in group experiments when necessary

courseDescription: Laboratory experiments are designed to complement the topics in the companion lecture course, CHEM 123N.  CHEM 123N + CHEM 124N satisfy 4 credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement.

courseTitle: Foundations of Chemistry II Lab with Introduction to Chemical Research
courseDescription: This course introduces students to foundational laboratory skills and research in the chemical sciences. Students will gain experience in experimental design and chemical research through a rotation in a faculty member's research lab.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration in a research lab setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a research lab

courseTitle: Introduction to Chemistry and Biochemistry Research and Careers
courseDescription: This course introduces students to information literacy and research in chemistry and biochemistry in the context of future career success. Students will develop skills in searching, evaluating, and citing information required for research projects. Potential career paths and strategies for student success will be investigated to establish a solid platform for development as a chemist or biochemist. Course activities will include field trips to and guest speakers from local industry.

Students will explore the role biotechnology plays in understanding and advancing nutrition and the effects this has on human health, development and societies. The key biological molecules such as vitamins, amino acids, proteins, fats and carbohydrates and their nutritional functions will be discussed. Nutritional biochemistry as it relates to human development, medicine and the evolution of human species will be explored. Students will review present day nutritional issues such as popular diets, organic foods, farming practices and advances such as genetically modified foods.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of key biological molecules (vitamins, amino acids, proteins, fats, carbohydrates)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration on research projects related to nutritional biochemistry
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of nutrition on human health and societies
Critical evaluation of present day nutritional issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing data related to nutritional biochemistry

courseDescription: Neurotechnology is the technology used to understand (assessment neurotechnology) and moderate (intervention neurotechnology) brain chemistry with regards to various aspects of consciousness, thought, memory, perception, addiction and other higher order activities and disorders in the brain. From pharmaceutical drugs to brain scanning, the impact of neurotechnology affects nearly everyone either directly or indirectly - for example: drug use for depression, sleep, ADD, or neurotic behavior; cancer scanning; stroke rehabilitation; etc. This course will explore the basics of neurotechnology and its impact on human behavior and performance as well as broader impacts on society. Further, students will learn how neurotechnology is used to assess and intervene in the neurochemistry of the brain with a particular emphasis on addictive behavior and neurodegenerative disorders.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex neurotechnology concepts to non-specialists
Collaborating with multidisciplinary teams in neurotechnology projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing neurotechnology data for patterns and insights
Developing interventions based on neurochemical assessments
Addressing addictive behavior and neurodegenerative disorders through neurotechnology
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing neurotechnology interventions in clinical settings

courseDescription: Selected laboratory or lecture topics designed for students who need to supplement a transfer course to fulfill a course requirement.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative teamwork in a lab setting

courseTitle: Undergraduate Research Experience in Chemistry and Biochemistry
courseDescription: Student participation in a supervised, undergraduate research experience for which credit will not apply to the degree.  Experience must be related to the student's major, minor or career area of interest.
Technical and Digital Skills: Laboratory techniques in chemistry and biochemistry
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear and concise written communication of results
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a research team towards project goals

courseDescription: Introduction to organic compounds, isomerism and nomenclature, stereochemistry and conformational analysis, in depth mechanistic understanding of proton transfer reactions, substitution and elimination reactions, and addition to C=C bonds.
Technical and Digital Skills: Mechanistic understanding of proton transfer reactions

courseDescription: Experience is offered in fundamental laboratory techniques applicable to the characterization, separation and purification of various organic compounds including stereoisomers and introduction to organic reactions.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimental design for organic compound analysis

courseDescription: Chemistry of carbon compounds with in-depth treatments of reaction mechanisms, modern spectral techniques, and new synthetic methods to meet the needs of chemistry and biochemistry majors.
Experience is offered in synthetic,  separation, and analytical methods of organic chemistry.  Modern synthetic and spectroscopic techniques are introduced.
Experience is offered in advanced organic reactions and spectroscopic techniques. In addition, students will carry out a short, customized, research project in Organic Chemistry or Organic Materials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research project execution in Organic Chemistry or Organic Materials
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data analysis and interpretation in organic reactions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project planning and execution in a laboratory setting

courseDescription: A study of the fundamental principles of quantitative chemical analysis including the application of principles of equilibria to analytical processes.  Emphasis is given to gravimetric and titrimetric methods as well as consideration of electrical, optical, and other methods of chemical analysis.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of equilibria principles to analytical processes

courseDescription: Statistical principles or measurements and error analysis are integrated with experiments designed to evaluate and refine techniques of fundamental measurements to a level of analytical competency.  These techniques are applied to the analysis of samples using gravimetric, titrimetric, electrical and optical methods.
Quantum chemistry, molecular structure, and spectroscopy.

A laboratory class focusing on a variety of physical chemical techniques. Topics may include electronic, vibrational (Raman) and NMR spectroscopies, calorimetry, viscosity, and atomic force microscopy. This is a writing intensive course, aiming to achieve an in-depth understanding of the physical principles underlying the techniques.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective written communication of experimental procedures and results
Collaboration with lab partners for experiments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying sources of error in measurements
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a group in experimental procedures

courseDescription: Chemical thermodynamics of pure substances and solutions, chemical equilibrium, electrochemistry, chemical kinetics, and statistical thermodynamics.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on course material

courseDescription: A laboratory class focusing on a variety of physical chemical techniques. Topics may include X-Ray Diffraction, Bomb Calorimetry, Thermal Gravimetric Analysis (TGA), Conductance of Solutions, and Polymer Physical Properties. This course may also include a team project that will incorporate many of the techniques learned in the physical chemistry lab sequence.  This project will introduce the students to working as a team to address a specific challenge such as one might encounter in an industrial or government laboratory setting.  This is a writing intensive course.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying sources of error in experiments

courseDescription: This class explores the impact of chemical technologies on current environmental topics using basic chemical principles and the scientific method as standards for evaluating and understanding pressing environmental issues. Topics include global and ocean warming, air pollution, atmospheric ozone depletion, effects of enhanced UV light, acid rain and ocean acidification, toxic heavy metals, radioactivity and nuclear power plant disasters, indoor air quality and radon, water pollution, sewage and water treatment, drinking water quality, waste disposal and plastics, pesticides, and the food chain. The course will use math to a modest degree including basic Algebra. It is highly recommended that students have passed a college level algebra math class (e.g., MATH 102M or MATH 103M or higher) and one year of high school chemistry.
Technical and Digital Skills: Scientific method application in environmental analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying chemical solutions to environmental problems
Evaluating the impact of chemical technologies on the environment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing group discussions on environmental topics

courseDescription: This combined lecture and lab course will explore the chemical and physical properties of artists’ materials from pigments and binders to ceramics. Topics will include the nature of light and color, historical origins and development of pigments and artistic methods, synthesis of dyes and pigments, and the application of technology to art historical analysis. The course will include hands-on experience with modern laboratory equipment and field trips to local museums and conservation labs.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing physical properties of artists' materials
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating field trips to museums and conservation labs
Leading group projects in the lab

courseDescription: This foundational course provides an introduction to inorganic chemistry.  Topics include periodic law, bonding theory, oxidation/reduction, acid/base theory, descriptive chemistry of the main group, an introduction to transition metal coordination chemistry, and human applications of inorganic chemistry.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing descriptive chemistry of main group elements
Problem-solving in human applications of inorganic chemistry

courseDescription: Synthesis of metal and nonmetal inorganic compounds and organometallic compounds, their characterization by physical methods, and a study of their properties.
Teaching experience in a chemistry classroom or laboratory setting under the direct supervision of the course instructor.  Available for Pass/Fail grading only.

May be repeated for credit.  Student participation for credit is based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the Cooperative Education program prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.  Available for pass/fail grading only.  (qualifies as a CAP experience)
A student may choose a coop, internship, research, or student teaching experience to gain out-of-class experience related to the major.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear and concise writing for lab reports
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for multiple research projects

courseTitle: Natural Products Chemistry in the Caribbean
courseDescription: A bioinorganic and natural products course that entails the chemistry of the use of chromium, vanadium, and herbs in medicine and the use of tunicates as biomonitors of heavy metal pollution in Jamaica. This is a study abroad course intended for the Maymester term.
Technical and Digital Skills: Chemical analysis of chromium and vanadium
Laboratory techniques in natural products chemistry
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings to diverse audiences
Networking with local experts in Jamaica
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data from natural products research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research team dynamics during the Maymester term

courseDescription: An in-depth look at organic reaction mechanisms, including polar, pericyclic, radical and organometallic reactions.

Designed to be taken concurrently with CHEM 422/CHEM 522.  A study of the basic principles of spectroscopic, chromatographic, and electrochemical methods of quantitative chemical analysis.  Methods of chemical instrumentation are also included.

An intensive laboratory study of the principles of analytical chemistry.  Experiments in spectroscopic, chromatographic, and electrochemical methods are conducted to illustrate fundamental principles and to provide the opportunity to develop skills in the use of instrumentation for chemical measurement.

An introduction to the fundamental concepts of drug action including pharmacodynamics (effect of drugs on the body) and pharmacokinetics (ADME: absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination) of drugs; an introduction to the process of new drug discovery and synthesis will also be taught.
This course is a one-semester survey of the major molecular constituents, bioenergetics, enzymes, nucleic acid structure, and genetic information transfer pathways fundamental to biochemistry.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking in genetic information transfer

courseDescription: Principles and techniques of biochemical and immunological procedures involving protein characterization and isolation, enzymology, bioinformatics, and common molecular biology techniques for nucleic acids will be presented. This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Molecular biology techniques for nucleic acids

courseDescription: This course presents and in-depth study of protein structure, folding, and synthesis.  The major metabolic pathways will be studied in detail regarding thermodynamics and mechanism of regulation or control of individual enzymes and entire metabolic pathways.  Concepts of metabolic disease will be introduced and effects on integrated metabolism will be presented.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of regulatory mechanisms in metabolism

courseDescription: An overview of the natural chemical systems operating in the atmosphere, in the terrestrial environment (both water and soils), and in the oceans, and the potential effects that human activities may have on them. Specific topics include the origin and evolution of the earth and life, the chemistry of the atmosphere (including the ozone layer and greenhouse effect), the organic and inorganic components of soil and water, chemical weathering of rocks, metal complexation, biological processes in soil and water, and global-scale chemical processes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding chemical systems in the atmosphere, terrestrial environments, and oceans
Analyzing the chemistry of the ozone layer and greenhouse effect
Biological processes in soil and water
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting scientific findings to diverse audiences
Collaborating with multidisciplinary teams on environmental projects
Communicating complex chemical concepts in layman's terms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying potential impacts of human activities on natural chemical systems
Conducting data analysis on environmental samples
Evaluating the effects of chemical processes on ecosystems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and coordinating fieldwork for environmental research
Managing research projects related to environmental chemistry

courseDescription: Theoretical aspects of modern inorganic chemistry:  bonding theories, stereochemistry, acid-base theories, coordination compounds, organometallic and bioinorganic compounds.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of organometallic compound properties

courseDescription: Synthesis of metal and nonmetal inorganic compounds and organometallic  compounds, their characterization by modern physical methods, and a study of their properties.

Fundamental principles of toxicology: dose-response relationship, toxicologic testing, chemical and biological factors influencing toxicity, organ toxicology, carcinogenesis, mutagenesis, teratogenesis.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of chemical and biological factors influencing toxicity

courseDescription: Nanotechnology presents unparalleled opportunities for advances in technology and medicine.  Simultaneously, nanotechnology presents new challenges to organisms and to our environment.  These undefined risk factors threaten to slow the development of new technologies and novel medical therapies.  This course will review: structure, synthesis and properties of key nanomaterials; key applications of nanomaterials in technology and medicine; and impacts of nanomaterials on plant and animal physiology and the environment more generally.  This course will be team-taught by faculty members in Biological Sciences, Chemistry and Biochemistry, and Engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of key applications in nanotechnology and medicine
Awareness of nanomaterial impacts on plant and animal physiology and the environment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with faculty members from different disciplines (Biological Sciences, Chemistry, Biochemistry, Engineering)
Effective communication of complex scientific concepts to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the potential risks and benefits of nanotechnology advancements
Identifying solutions to challenges in nanotechnology development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking initiative in exploring new research directions in nanoscience and nanotechnology

courseTitle: Research Methods in Mathematics and Science
courseDescription: Emphasizes the tools and techniques used to solve scientific problems.  Topics include use and design of experiments, use of statistics to interpret experimental results, mathematical modeling of scientific phenomena, and oral and written presentation of scientific results. Students will perform four independent inquiries, combining skills from mathematics and science to solve research problems. Required for Chemistry teaching licensure track; not available as upper-division elective in content area.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective oral communication of scientific results
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Integration of mathematics and science to solve research problems
Identification of research gaps and opportunities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for multiple research tasks

courseDescription: The formal presentation of a chemical or biochemical topic before students and faculty.  Students will also take Major Field Test during this course.

Part one of a two-semester thesis project involving literature research, development of scientific writing skills, and obtaining lab experience using a variety of techniques and equipment.  Each student will undertake a research experience under the supervision of a departmental faculty member.  A preliminary report of research findings is required at the end of the semester.

A high level of economic activity and development for any industrialized nation has at its core a strong STEM component. Within this component, the fields of chemistry and biochemistry form one of the strongest inter-disciplinary links by providing an understanding of the processes and products at a molecular level. This course will allow students to combine their academic knowledge in chemistry and biochemistry with the needs of real-world businesses to formulate an economically viable business plan that encompasses a scientifically and economically sound proof-of-concept.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying market gaps for chemical innovations
Analyzing scientific data for business decisions
Developing innovative solutions to scientific challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for scientific business growth

courseDescription: Study of selected topics.
An opportunity is afforded students to undertake independent study or an original investigation under the direction of a faculty member.
An opportunity is afforded students to undertake independent study or an original investigation under the direction of a faculty member.
Continuation of CHEM 490.  The research culminates in a thesis that includes a literature review, description of methods, results and conclusions, and an oral presentation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying research gaps and proposing solutions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for meeting thesis deadlines

courseDescription: An in-depth look at organic reaction mechanisms, including polar, pericyclic, radical and organometallic reactions.

Designed to be taken concurrently with CHEM 522.  A study of the basic principles of spectroscopic, chromatographic, and electrochemical methods of quantitative chemical analysis.  Methods of chemical instrumentation are also included.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for instrument analysis tasks

courseDescription: An intensive laboratory study of the principles of analytical chemistry.  Experiments in spectroscopic, chromatographic, and electrochemical methods are conducted to illustrate fundamental principles and to provide the opportunity to develop skills in the use of instrumentation for chemical measurement.

An introduction to the fundamental concepts of drug action including pharmacodynamics (effect of drugs on the body) and pharmacokinetics (ADME: absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination) of drugs; an introduction to the process of new drug discovery and synthesis will also be taught.
This course is a one-semester survey of the major molecular constituents, bioenergetics, enzymes, nucleic acid structure, and genetic information transfer pathways fundamental to biochemistry.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key factors in bioenergetics processes

courseDescription: Principles and techniques of biochemical and immunological procedures involving protein characterization and isolation, enzymology, bioinformatics, and common molecular biology techniques for nucleic acids will be presented. (This is a writing intensive course.)
Technical and Digital Skills: Molecular biology techniques for nucleic acids
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective scientific writing for biochemical procedures

courseDescription: This course presents and in-depth study of protein structure, folding, and synthesis.  The major metabolic pathways will be studied in detail regarding thermodynamics and mechanism of regulation or control of individual enzymes and entire metabolic pathways.  Concepts of metabolic disease will be introduced and effects on integrated metabolism will  be presented.

An overview of the natural chemical systems operating in the atmosphere, in the terrestrial environment (both water and soils), and in the oceans, and the potential effects that human activities may have on them. Specific topics include the origin and evolution of the earth and life, the chemistry of the atmosphere (including the ozone layer and greenhouse effect), the organic and inorganic components of soil and water, chemical weathering of rocks, metal complexation, biological processes in soil and water, and global-scale chemical processes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding chemical systems in the atmosphere, water, and soil
Knowledge of ozone layer and greenhouse effect chemistry
Biological processes in soil and water
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of environmental chemistry concepts to diverse audiences
Collaboration with experts in related fields such as ecology and geology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of human activities on natural chemical systems
Identifying potential solutions to mitigate environmental harm caused by chemical processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on environmental chemistry topics
Organizing and coordinating research projects related to environmental impact assessment

courseDescription: Theoretical aspects of modern inorganic chemistry:  bonding theories, stereochemistry, acid-base theories, coordination compounds, organometallic and bioinorganic compounds.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing biological applications of inorganic chemistry

courseDescription: Advanced topics in inorganic synthesis.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with lab partners on experiments
Presenting findings to peers and instructors
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively during lab sessions

courseDescription: Fundamental principles of toxicology: dose-response relationship, toxicologic testing, chemical and biological factors influencing toxicity, organ toxicology, carcinogenesis, mutagenesis, teratogenesis.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of chemical and biological factors influencing toxicity
Recognizing carcinogenesis, mutagenesis, and teratogenesis pathways
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with multidisciplinary teams for toxicity assessments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing toxicological data for risk assessment
Identifying potential toxicological hazards in different scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating toxicology studies with external partners

courseDescription: Nanotechnology presents unparalleled opportunities for advances in technology and medicine.  Simultaneously, nanotechnology presents new challenges to organisms and to our environment.  These undefined risk factors threaten to slow the development of new technologies and novel medical therapies.  This course will review: structure, synthesis and properties of key nanomaterials; key applications of nanomaterials in technology and medicine; and impacts of nanomaterials on plant and animal physiology and the environment more generally.  This course will be team-taught by faculty members in Biological Sciences, Chemistry and Biochemistry, and Engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applications of nanomaterials in technology and medicine
Assessment of nanomaterial impacts on plant and animal physiology
Knowledge of environmental impacts of nanomaterials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective team collaboration with faculty members from different disciplines
Clear communication of complex scientific concepts to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of nanomaterial research findings
Problem-solving in assessing risks and benefits of nanotechnology advancements
Analytical skills in interpreting data on nanomaterial properties and impacts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordination of interdisciplinary team efforts in teaching and learning
Leadership in promoting responsible use of nanotechnology for societal benefit

courseDescription: Study of selected topics.
6 credits; 50 hours per credit.  One semester of work experience in local hospital, forensic, or industrial laboratory.  Available for pass/fail grading only.

An introduction to graduate studies in chemistry.  Topics include responsible conduct of research (RCR), grant writing skills, oral presentation of chemical research and methods for searching the chemical literature.  Attendance at departmental seminars is required.  Limited to first-year chemistry doctoral students.
Topics representing the most recent advances in various fields of chemistry or ones which represent an interdisciplinary advancement.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting complex scientific concepts to non-experts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of cutting-edge research findings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for innovative chemical projects

courseDescription: Study of selected topics in chemistry.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective scientific communication with peers and instructors

Technical and Digital Skills: Software tools proficiency for data analysis (e.g., SPSS, R)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with advisors and committee members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking and evaluation of research literature
Development of research frameworks and models

courseDescription: The theoretical and practical foundation of analysis with emphasis on recent analytical developments and current literature; topics may include figures of merit and data treatment, sampling and extraction, HPLC, electrochemistry, circular dichroism, FT-IR, Raman, MS, electrophoresis and NMR.  Lectures are given by experts in those techniques.

This course will review the most cutting-edge advanced analytical chemistry instrumentation and methods, spanning three core areas of analytical chemistry (spectroscopy, separation, and electrochemistry) and offering an in-depth understanding of objectives, motivations, and future directions. The course will focus on advanced instrumentation and methodologies that can achieve ultra-sensitive analysis and detection, including single molecular spectroscopy, nanoparticle probes, high-speed separation in microfluidic devices, and ultramicroelectrodes for sensing and imaging.
Technical and Digital Skills: Operation of advanced analytical chemistry instrumentation
Microfluidic device operation for high-speed separation
Ultramicroelectrode handling for sensing and imaging
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Optimization of analytical methods for ultra-sensitive analysis

courseTitle: Chromatographic Separations by HPLC and GC
courseDescription: This course covers basic principles of  chromatography emphasizing high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and gas chromatography (GC), as well as separation modes, instrumentation, detection methods, quantification, and sample preparation including solid phase extraction.  Examples from environmental sciences, biosciences and industry will be stressed.
This lab course consists of six to seven independent HPLC and GC exercises based on examples from environmental, bioscience, and industrial applications.

courseTitle: Automation and Management of the Clinical Chemistry Laboratory
courseDescription: The basic principles of management of the clinical chemistry laboratory and regulatory issues in laboratory management are presented.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective team communication in laboratory settings
Collaboration with regulatory bodies for compliance
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation for decision-making in laboratory management
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing regulatory changes in laboratory protocols

courseDescription: This course presents the fundamental principals and practical applications of modern electrochemical methods of analysis. Lectures and text readings cover the basic concepts and fundamental principals of this division of analytical techniques.  Detailed descriptions and demonstrations of modern electrochemical research instrumentation will be provided.  Students will obtain hands-on experience with this instrumentation by performing a required chemical determination using an electroanalytical method, and by undertaking a special analytical project.  Research applications of other electroanalytical techniques and instrumentation, in addition to those actually used by the students in this course, will be discussed and/or demonstrated.
Technical and Digital Skills: Performing chemical determinations using electroanalytical methods
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing research applications of electroanalytical techniques
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating research activities with team members

courseDescription: A hands-on approach to experimental design and multivariate data analysis.  Modern computer-based chemometric theories will be presented.

An examination of the design of complex organic molecules and natural products. Topics covered will include: retrosynthetic analysis; stereochemical control; application of fundamental organic reactions to develop synthetic strategies; implementation of protecting groups in organic synthesis; construction of carbocyclic and heterocyclic ring systems, organometallic coupling reactions, and contemporary methods.
Technical and Digital Skills: Carbocyclic and heterocyclic ring systems construction

courseDescription: This course is a survey of the mechanisms of biochemical activity of the trace elements.  Topics include oxygen uptake, oxidation-reduction, metabolism, and toxicity.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding biochemical mechanisms of trace elements
Familiarity with oxidation-reduction reactions in biological systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing metabolism pathways of trace elements
Identifying potential toxicity mechanisms in biological systems

courseDescription: Approaches to the study of reaction mechanisms, including molecular orbital theory, thermochemistry, kinetics, isotop effects, solvent and substituent effects (including linear free energy relationships), acidity, acid catalysis, and detection of reactive intermediates.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key factors in acidity and acid catalysis

courseDescription: Study of the chemistry and mode of action of various medicinal and physiologically active compounds.

A comprehensive evaluation of modern organic transformations with emphasis on the fundamentals of each reaction, their utility and applications.  Topics covered will include: nomenclature, classes of compounds, functional group exchanges (oxidation and reduction reactions), bond forming reactions (carbon-carbon, carbon-oxygen, and carbon-nitrogen), introduction to protecting groups, and reaction control by steric, electronic and topological considerations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of nomenclature in organic chemistry
Application of oxidation and reduction reactions
Utilization of protecting groups in reactions
Control of reactions based on steric, electronic, and topological factors

courseDescription: Organic functional group and structure analysis with ultraviolet, infrared, nuclear magnetic resonance, mass, and other spectroscopic techniques.
Technical and Digital Skills: Interpreting ultraviolet, infrared, nuclear magnetic resonance, and mass spectra
Utilizing spectroscopic techniques for structure analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying unknown compounds through spectroscopic data
Evaluating spectral peaks for compound characterization

courseDescription: Detailed coverage of fundamental organic transformations with emphasis on reduction, oxidation, carbon-carbon bond formation, and protecting group strategy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to perform carbon-carbon bond formation

courseDescription: This course examines important transformations of organotransition-metal species. There is an emphasis on basic mechanism, structure-reactivity relationships, and applications in organic synthesis with applications of organotransition-metal catalysis towards industrial applications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing organotransition-metal catalysis in organic synthesis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing industrial applications of organotransition-metal catalysis
Evaluating the effectiveness of organometallic reactions in organic synthesis
Identifying key factors influencing reactivity in organometallic chemistry

courseDescription: This course is based on the coordination and transition metal chemistry of first row, second row, and third row transition metals.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting spectroscopic data in metal complexes

courseDescription: This course trains students in the theory and application of advanced mass spectrometric methods as used in all subdisciplines of chemistry and biochemistry.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data interpretation and analysis in mass spectrometry
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of mass spectrometric data
Identification of chemical compounds using mass spectrometry

courseDescription: Organic geochemistry is the study of organic compounds originally produced by photosynthesis and altered as they cycle through the soils, atmosphere, rivers, oceans, and crustal rocks.  This course will include the carbon/oxygen cycles, biomarkers, organic matter diagenesis/catagenesis, analytical techniques used in organic geochemistry, and an introduction to carbon isotopes.

NMR is a highly specific spectroscopic technique. It can probe the individual atoms in molecules via a limitless array of distinct experiments tailored to nearly every need. While NMR experiments can contain up to several hundred magnetic pulses, the effect of the pulses and therefore the utility of each experiment can be understood via a primarily visual approach. This course offers a visual-based approach to discuss spectrometer hardware, basic NMR theory, and a series of one, two and three-dimensional NMR experiments, with applications to small molecules, proteins, nucleic acids and their interactions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Executing one, two, and three-dimensional NMR experiments
Interpreting magnetic pulses in NMR experiments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying atoms in molecules using NMR spectra

courseDescription: This course focuses on the applied biochemistry associated with human biological systems. Topics to be covered include the hormonal control of metabolism, vitamins, minerals, diagnostic tests; the biochemistry of the digestive system; connective tissue and bone; the immune system; the urinary system; and the nervous systems, among others. Exams involve answering United States Medical Licensing Exam type questions in some instances. Medical biochemistry case studies are presented and discussed in class that relate to the biochemical basis of disease to enhance the learning experience. Students will also write a research paper and give an in-class presentation on selected topics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of medical biochemistry concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of medical biochemistry case studies
Analyzing biochemical processes in human biological systems
Identifying connections between biochemistry and disease
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively for exams and presentations

courseDescription: Study of the basic principles and methods of trace chemical analysis of environmental systems, including spectroscopic, chromatographic, and electrochemical instrumental methods, in addition to wet chemical methods.

An overview of the natural chemistry systems operating in the atmosphere, in the terrestrial environment (both water and soils), and in the oceans, and the potential effects that human activities may have on them.  Specific topics include the origin and evolution of the earth and life, the chemistry of the atmosphere (including the ozone layer and greenhouse effect), the organic and inorganic components of soil and water, chemical weathering of rocks, metal complexation, biological processes in soil and water, and global-scale chemical processes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data interpretation and analysis in environmental contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with multidisciplinary teams on environmental projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of chemical processes in environmental systems
Problem-solving in assessing human impact on natural systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of data for environmental studies

courseDescription: Overview of the development and application of quantum mechanics from a chemical perspective.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of complex scientific concepts
Collaborative research in quantum chemistry projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation in quantum chemistry experiments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in quantum chemistry research

courseDescription: Comprehensive overview of ab initio (quantum) calculations and molecular dynamic simulations, the two most widely used computational methods.  Plus a brief overview of other computational applications in chemistry and biology.
Technical and Digital Skills: Computational applications in chemistry and biology

courseDescription: This course is a survey of the major mechanisms of inorganic and organometallic chemistry.  Topics include kinetics, ligand substitution, electron transfer, and photochemistry.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Predicting reaction outcomes based on mechanism

courseDescription: An introductory survey of atmospheric chemistry and physics. Topics to be covered include atmospheric composition, atmospheric pressure, simple models, atmospheric transport, geochemical cycles, the greenhouse effect, aerosols, stratospheric ozone, the oxidizing power of the troposphere, ozone air pollution, satellite orbits, and radiative transfer. The course will also provide a survey of satellite remote sensing. It will conclude with the basics of satellite remote sensing, including a brief survey of satellite instruments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with greenhouse effect and aerosols
Knowledge of satellite remote sensing basics
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex scientific concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the impact of stratospheric ozone depletion
Problem-solving for tropospheric ozone air pollution
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing satellite remote sensing data for analysis

courseDescription: An introductory survey of the rotational, vibrational and electronic spectroscopy of molecules from the perspective of quantum mechanics and group theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding rotational, vibrational, and electronic spectroscopy
Applying quantum mechanics to spectroscopic analysis
Utilizing group theory in molecular spectroscopy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying quantum principles to solve spectroscopic problems

courseTitle: Mechanisms of Sensing and Signal Transduction
courseDescription: Living organisms must sense and respond to changes in their environment, which requires perceiving extracellular stimuli and converting this information into tangible changes to intracellular function. Sensory and metabolic pathways must integrate stimuli from multiple signals to coordinate cell-wide or organism-wide responses, and signal transduction pathways must be considered in the context of the networks they comprise. Signal transduction networks are the very definition of ‘wholes’ that are greater and more complex than the sums of their parts. This course will have a dual focus on mechanisms of signal transduction, with an emphasis on macromolecular structure, and on network modeling.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of signal transduction mechanisms

courseDescription: This course will cover macromolecular structure, function, thermodynamic stability and folding kinetics; protein chemistry; molecular biology; and molecular mechanisms of disease and bioinformatics.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in molecular biology research

courseDescription: A comprehensive presentation of the chemistry of RNA and DNA, including modern concepts of gene regulation, the control over transcription, RNA processing and translation, cell cycle control and molecular carcinogenesis.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding the chemistry of RNA and DNA
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of complex biochemical concepts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to lead discussions on molecular carcinogenesis

courseDescription: This course will examine the physical characterization of macromolecules, polarized light, absorption and fluorescence, sedimentation and transport hydrodynamics, electrophoretic mobility, light scattering, and structural x-ray crystallography of proteins and nucleic acids.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving sedimentation and transport hydrodynamics problems

courseDescription: A survey of modern theories of reaction rates and mechanisms, classic  thermodynamic functions, and an introduction to statistical thermodynamics.

Students will learn cutting-edge bioinformatics and genomics approaches to gain an in depth understanding of genetic and protein evolution as it relates to genetic mutation and adaption and to protein structure, folding and function. The theory and computational skills needed to analyze protein, DNA and non-coding RNA sequences as well as protein structures will be taught and applied. Comparative genomics studies will be conducted, focusing on current topics such as viral outbreaks where students will elucidate functional variations leading to enhanced virulence in isolates during a pandemic such as Zika.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Functional variation elucidation in viral outbreaks

courseDescription: Master's students attend seminars given by researchers from across the country in order to expose them to additional areas of research in chemistry and biochemistry.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing research hypotheses based on seminar content

courseDescription: Master's students attend seminars, attend a class on giving seminars, and present a seminar on their own research.

courseTitle: Selected Topics in Chemistry and Biochemistry
courseDescription: Thorough coverage of areas selected to meet special needs and interests.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of research findings to peers
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating team efforts in the lab

courseDescription: This course will review the most cutting-edge advanced analytical chemistry instrumentation and methods, spanning three core areas of analytical chemistry (spectroscopy, separation, and electrochemistry) and offering an in-depth understanding of objectives, motivations, and future directions. The course will focus on advanced instrumentation and methodologies that can achieve ultra-sensitive analysis and detection, including single molecular spectroscopy, nanoparticle probes, high-speed separation in microfluidic devices, and ultramicroelectrodes for sensing and imaging.
Technical and Digital Skills: Operational knowledge of cutting-edge analytical chemistry instrumentation
Utilization of single molecular spectroscopy techniques
Experience in high-speed separation using microfluidic devices
Ability to work with ultramicroelectrodes for sensing and imaging
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation and analysis for ultra-sensitive detection methods

courseDescription: An examination of the design of complex organic molecules and natural products. Topics covered will include: retrosynthetic analysis; stereochemical control; application of fundamental organic reactions to develop synthetic strategies; implementation of protecting groups in organic synthesis; construction of carbocyclic and heterocyclic ring systems, organometallic coupling reactions, and contemporary methods
Technical and Digital Skills: Construction of carbocyclic and heterocyclic ring systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of organic reactions in synthesis

courseDescription: This course is a survey of the mechanisms of biochemical activity of the trace elements.  Topics include oxygen uptake, oxidation-reduction, metabolism, and toxicity.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding mechanisms of biochemical activity of trace elements
Understanding of oxidation-reduction reactions in biological systems
Metabolism analysis in a biochemical context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key factors in biochemical processes

courseDescription: Approaches to the study of reaction mechanisms, including molecular orbital theory, thermochemistry, kinetics, isotop effects, solvent and substituent effects (including linear free energy relationships), acidity, acid catalysis, and detection of reactive intermediates.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking in studying substituent effects

courseDescription: Study of the chemistry and mode of action of various medicinal and physiologically active compounds.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of research findings to peers and stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing biological pathways affected by compounds

courseDescription: A comprehensive evaluation of modern organic transformations with emphasis on the fundamentals of each reaction, their utility and applications. Topics covered will include: nomenclature, classes of compounds, functional group exchanges (oxidation and reduction reactions), bond forming reactions (carbon-carbon, carbon-oxygen, and carbon-nitrogen), introduction to protecting groups, and reaction control by steric, electronic and topological considerations
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to perform oxidation and reduction reactions
Skills in carbon-carbon, carbon-oxygen, and carbon-nitrogen bond formation
Control of reactions based on steric, electronic, and topological factors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying optimal reaction conditions based on chemical properties

courseDescription: Organic functional group and structure analysis with ultraviolet, infrared, nuclear magnetic resonance, mass, and other spectroscopic techniques.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing spectroscopic techniques for structure analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying functional groups in organic compounds

courseDescription: Detailed coverage of fundamental organic transformations with emphasis on reduction, oxidation, carbon-carbon bond formation, and protecting group strategy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to perform carbon-carbon bond formation

courseDescription: This course examines important transformations of organotransition-metal species. There is an emphasis on basic mechanism, structure-reactivity relationships, and applications in organic synthesis with applications of organotransition-metal catalysis towards industrial applications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing organotransition-metal catalysis in organic synthesis
Application of organometallic chemistry in industrial settings

courseDescription: This course examines the coordination and transition metal chemistry of first row, second row, and third row transition metals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing spectroscopic techniques for metal analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating complex chemical concepts to non-experts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting spectroscopic data for metal complexes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on metal coordination chemistry

courseDescription: This course trains students in the theory and application of advanced mass spectrometric methods as used in all subdisciplines of chemistry and biochemistry.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data interpretation and analysis in mass spectrometry
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of mass spectrometry data
Collaboration with research team members for data interpretation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of unknown compounds using mass spectrometry data
Optimization of mass spectrometry methods for specific applications
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for mass spectrometry experiments
Leading a research team in mass spectrometry data analysis

courseDescription: NMR is a highly specific spectroscopic technique. It can probe the individual atoms in molecules via a limitless array of distinct experiments tailored to nearly every need. While NMR experiments can contain up to several hundred magnetic pulses, the effect of the pulses and therefore the utility of each experiment can be understood via a primarily visual approach. This course offers a visual-based approach to discuss spectrometer hardware, basic NMR theory, and a series of one, two and three-dimensional NMR experiments, with applications to small molecules, proteins, nucleic acids and their interactions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementing one, two, and three-dimensional NMR experiments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex NMR concepts to others
Collaborating with peers on NMR experiments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of magnetic pulses on NMR experiments
Interpreting NMR results for different types of molecules
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading NMR experiment planning and execution

courseDescription: This course focuses on the applied biochemistry associated with human biological systems. Topics to be covered include the hormonal control of metabolism, vitamins, minerals, diagnostic tests; the biochemistry of the digestive system; connective tissue and bone; the immune system; the urinary system; and the nervous systems, among others. Exams involve answering United States Medical Licensing Exam type questions in some instances. Medical biochemistry case studies are presented and discussed in class that relate to the biochemical basis of disease to enhance the learning experience. Students will also write a research paper and give an in-class presentation on selected topics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding the biochemistry of the digestive system
Knowledge of connective tissue and bone biochemistry
Understanding the biochemistry of the immune system
Understanding the biochemistry of the nervous system
Ability to answer United States Medical Licensing Exam type questions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Participating in class discussions on the biochemical basis of disease
Writing a research paper on medical biochemistry
Delivering an in-class presentation on selected topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying biochemical knowledge to disease scenarios
Critically evaluating biochemistry research for the research paper
Solving complex biochemistry problems in exams
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on medical biochemistry topics
Coordinating in-class presentations on selected topics

Specific topics include the origin and evolution of the earth and life, the chemistry of the atmosphere (including the ozone layer and greenhouse effect), the organic and inorganic components of soil and water, chemical weathering of rocks, metal complexation, biological processes in soil and water, and global-scale chemical processes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding chemical reactions in natural systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex scientific concepts
Collaborative research in environmental chemistry projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting complex data sets related to environmental chemistry

courseDescription: Overview of the development and application of quantum mechanics from a chemical perspective.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex quantum concepts to non-experts
Collaborating on research projects with team members
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research projects in quantum chemistry
Leading discussions on quantum mechanics applications in chemistry

courseDescription: Comprehensive overview of ab initio (quantum) calculations and molecular dynamic simulations, the two most widely used computational methods. Plus a brief overview of other computational applications in chemistry and biology.

courseDescription: An introduction to statistical mechanics from a chemical perspective. Topics to be covered include ensembles and postulates and their mathematical background; basic thermodynamics; distinguishable and indistinguishable systems; ideal monatomic gas; monatomic crystals; ideal diatomic gas; ideal polyatomic gas; chemical equilibrium; rates of chemical reactions; and quantum statistics.
An introductory survey of the rotational, vibrational and electronic spectroscopy of molecules from the perspective of quantum mechanics and group theory.

This course will have a dual focus on mechanisms of signal transduction, with an emphasis on macromolecular structure, and on network modeling.

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team towards a common goal

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
